Incident.Summary: DUI 23-002 // CDS POSS: NOT MARIJUANA // RESISTING ARREST.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
Maryland State Police North East Barrack “F”
MSP unmarked vehicle F-10 is equipped with a mobile recording device. I, TFC Yocum #6934, am equipped with a body worn camera. The incident was recorded.

DEFENDANT: JOHNSON, MARTIN JAY
Date of Birth: 11/18/1974
Date of Arrest: 01/03/2023
Time of Arrest: 1031 hours (10:31 AM)
MD SDX#: J-525-585-379-883
DUI #: 23-002 (North East Barrack “F”)

TRAINING/CERTIFICATES:
* I am trained in administering standardized field sobriety tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA).
* I am trained in Advanced Roadside Impaired Driver Enforcement (ARIDE).
* I have apprehended more than 150 impaired drivers during my tenure with the Maryland State Police to date.

WITNESS: YOUNG, ROGER
20 Ballad Drive,
Newark, DE 19702
1(302)358-9291
** See attachments for written statement**

VEHICLE IN MOTION (PHASE 1):
On January 3, 2023, at approximately 0957 hours, I, Trooper First Class Yocum #6934 was on duty and in full uniform, operating Maryland State Police unmarked police cruiser F-10. At this time, I was dispatched to Route 40 (Pulaski Highway) at Delancy Road for a driver passed out behind the wheel. I was advised the vehicle was a silver Honda Ridgeline. While en route to the location of vehicle, I observed a silver Honda Ridgeline displaying Maryland registration “8DM9902” turning left on to Red Hill Road as I was turning right onto Delancy Road (3 minutes, 40 seconds mark of dash cam footage).

Upon checking the area of Route 40 and Delancy Road, I did not observe a Honda Ridgeline with a driver asleep behind the wheel. I then began checking the area of Red Hill Road in attempt to relocate the Honda Ridgeline I observed earlier. I was able to relocate the Honda Ridgeline at 33 Keithley Lane, Elkton, MD 21921 (8 minutes, 26 seconds mark of dash cam footage). The approximate time from when I first observed the Honda at Red Hill Road and Delancy Road to when I located it at 33 Keithley Lane was approximately 4 minutes, 46 seconds.

PERSONAL CONTACT (PHASE 2):   
Upon locating the Honda Ridgeline, I contacted the driver, who would be identified through the MVA as Martin Jay Johnson (DOB: 11/18/1974 2/M). Johnson advised he was coming from the dollar store. I advised Johnson the reason I was there because a witness observed him asleep behind the wheel, to which Johnson stated, “No I was reading the manual, I’m trying to find a tire for this truck.” I asked Johnson for his identification card, to which he advised he didn’t have on his person. While speaking with Johnson, I observed damage to the front driver-side quarter panel of the Honda Ridgeline. Johnson advised that his keys were inside the camper. Johnson then began walking towards the camper, and I advised him to stay put. Upon the arrival of TFC Rafer #6709, I had him stand with Johnson, and I returned to my patrol vehicle to contact the complainant, Roger Young.

Young advised that he was leaving Walmart (1000 E Pulaski Highway, Elkton, MD 21921) and the silver Honda Ridgeline was sitting in front of him. Young advised the traffic light had changed, but the Ridgeline had remained stationary. Young advised that he had honked his horn multiple times, and he didn’t move. Upon the Ridgeline sitting through another traffic light sequence, Young advised that he drove his vehicle up along aside of the driver-side of Ridgeline, and observed Johnson to be asleep behind the wheel while the Ridgeline was running.  Young described Johnson as approximately a 50-year-old white male, with brown hair and he was heavy set. Young then advised of the damage to the front driver-side quarter panel of the Ridgeline. Young advised he contacted 911, and began driving away as Johnson was still asleep.

I then re-initiated contact with Johnson and captured two pictures of his face to send to Young to see if he could positively identify Johnson as the driver. Upon sending Young the two pictures, Young advised that Johnson appeared to be the driver. While in contact with Johnson, he appeared to be lethargic and his pupils appeared to be constricted. While speaking with Johnson, I observed his voice to be mumbled and raspy. I also observed his right nostril to be flared. I know through my training, knowledge, and experience as a Maryland State Trooper from numerous DUI arrests, that the aforementioned is indicative of snorting controlled dangerous substances. At this time, I re-initiated contact with Johnson and requested him to perform Standardized Field Sobriety Tests, to which he would agree to the tests.

PRE-ARREST SCREENING (PHASE 3):
The evaluation was performed in the roadway of Keithley Lane. The surface was solid, flat, and free from any debris. The weather condition at the time was no precipitation and approximately 55 degrees. Lighting conditions consisted of daylight. My patrol vehicle's forward emergency lights were deactivated during all three tests. Johnson appeared to be in good physical condition and did not display any visible injuries. I asked Johnson the following questions:

I asked Johnson if he saw my police car turn onto Delancy Road as he was also turning from Delancy, to which Johnson stated, “yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah.” I advised Johnson that myself and TFC Rafer were en route to locate him.

Medication – None.
Physical injuries/ disabilities – Got bitten by a dog on both legs. Pinched nerve in back.
Glasses/ Contacts – None.

I asked Johnson the last time he consumed an alcoholic beverage, to which he stated, “15 years ago.”
I asked Johnson if he ever had any experience using drugs, to which he stated, “15 years ago.”

I asked Johnson if I had to him walk in a straight line, or if he was able to balance on one foot, to which Johnson advised he could.

I asked Johnson where he was coming from today, to which he stated, “277 Maloney Road.” I then stated to Johnson, “ I thought you were coming from the Dollar General?” Johnson then stated the following:
“Yeah, I went to dollar general, then I went to Walmart. Then I came, then when I left Walmart I was sitting at the red light there at Walmart and that’s when I looked on the phone. I was going to go right and go into Delaware and try and find a tire.”

Johnson then advised that he drove to Keithley Lane to contact a friend of his to assist him with getting a tire for his truck.   

HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS (6/6 clues observed)
I gave instructions on how the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test was to be performed. I asked Johnson if he understood all instructions and demonstrations, to which he stated, “Yes.”

1.) Lack of Smooth Pursuit- Present in both eyes.
2.) Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation- Present in both eyes.
3.) Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees- Present in both eyes.
*Vertical Nystagmus was present in both eyes*               

*While doing the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus tests, I observed Johnson sway back and forth from front to back. *

WALK AND TURN (7/8 clues observed)
I gave instructions and fully demonstrated how the Walk and Turn test was to be performed. I asked Johnson if he understood all instructions and demonstrations, to which he stated, “Yes.”

Instructional Stage:
1.) Cannot keep balance.
2.) Starts too soon.

Walking Stage (1st Nine):

1.) Missed heel to toe.
2.) Steps off line.
3.) Raised arms for balance.
4.) Stopped walking.

Turn: Completed unsatisfactory
Johnson did not leave his lead foot planted.

Walking Stage (2nd Nine):

1.) Missed heel to toe.
2.) Steps off line.

ONE LEG STAND (3/4 clues observed)
I gave instructions and fully demonstrated how the One Leg Stand test was to be performed. I asked Johnson if he understood all instructions and demonstrations, to which he stated, “Yes.”
Seconds 0-30:
1.) Raised arms for balance.
2.) Swayed back and forth.
3.) Put foot down.


ARREST:
Based on the following, I had reason to believe Johnson was driving under the influence:

- Vehicle in motion, asleep behind the wheel. (SEE WITNESS STATEMENT)
- Constricted pupils.
- Mumbled and raspy speech
- Flared nostril.
- Swaying while standing.
- Clues observed during standardized field sobriety testing.

Due to the number of observations, I concluded Johnson was driving under the influence and unable to operate a vehicle safely. At approximately 1031 hours, I placed Johnson under arrest for Driving While Under the Influence. At this time, I told Johnson to place his hands on the front hood of my patrol cruiser. I then advised Johnson that he was going to be placed under arrest. Upon retrieving my handcuffs, I cuffed Johnson’s right wrist. Due to Johnson’s larger size, and poor flexibility I was unable to handcuff his left wrist.
I had TFC Rafer #6709 standby and watch Johnson as I went to my patrol cruiser to retrieve another set of handcuffs. As I was walking to my front driver-side door of my patrol cruiser, Johnson began resisting arrest and attempted to flee on foot.  As I turned around I observed TFC Rafer attempting to maintain control of Johnson, which caused Johnson to fall to the ground, and TFC Rafer fall and land on top of him.
I retrieved another pair of handcuffs from my patrol cruiser, and ran to aid TFC Rafer in regaining control of Johnson.  I gave Johnson the verbal command of “Put your hands behind your back,” to which he refused. While Johnson was on the ground laying on his stomach, I positioned myself by his right shoulder area. I used a strong-arm muscling technique to regain control of Johnsons right wrist and placed it behind the small of his back. TFC Rafer gained control of his left arm, and placed it behind the small of his back. TFC Rafer then cuffed his left wrist with a separate pair of handcuffs. I then cuffed both sets of handcuffs together. Once compliance was gained, all force was ceased.

Myself and TFC Rafer escorted Johnson to my patrol cruiser. TFC Rafer conducted a secondary search on scene and the following was located through search incident to arrest:

One (1) plastic bag containing a white powdery substance and clear rock-like matter, suspected cocaine and methamphetamine, located in Johnsons front left pants pocket.
One (1) blue wax paper fold labeled “Only Fans” containing a white powdery substance, suspected heroin, located in Johnsons left front pants pocket.
One (1) blue wax paper fold labeled “Show and Tell” containing a white powdery substance, suspected heroin, located in the front driver-side door pocket of the Honda Ridgeline MD registration “8DM9902.”
One (1) glass smoking device containing trace amounts of a white powdery substance, suspected cocaine, located in Johnsons right front pants pocket.

I know through my training, knowledge, and experience as a Maryland State Trooper from numerous drug arrests, that Heroin is a scheduled I controlled dangerous substance, methamphetamine is a schedule II controlled dangerous substance, and cocaine is scheduled II controlled dangerous substance.

All contraband seized was transported to the Maryland State Police Barrack, processed, verified by Cpl. Siemek #6684, stored as evidence on property held number: P-337999. All contraband was requested to examined and tested.

Johnson was transported to the Maryland State Police North East Barrack, and upon arrival was met by Cecil County Medics to be medically evaluated. Johnson would be transported to the Union Hospital on Cecil County Medic 491 (Run number: 2023000693).

I followed Medic 491 and Johnson to Union Hospital and upon our arrival, I re-initiated contact with Johnson in the back of the ambulance. Johnson was advised of his DR-15 Advice of Rights in English. Johnson was also provided a copy to view. At 1148 hours (11:48 AM), Johnson elected to refuse the blood kit.

20-MINUTE OBSERVATION PERIOD:
N/A

INTOXIMETER RESULTS:
All appropriate citations were issued to Johnson and he was provided copies of all pertinent paperwork. Johnson was advised that I would re-initiate contact him pending application for statement of charges for CDS possession and resisting arrest. Johnson would be released to the care of Union Hospital.

I request this case remain open pending application for statement of charges.

All events occurred in Cecil County, Maryland.

IncidentProperty.Description: Two (2) blue wax paper folds labeled "Only Fans" and "Show and Tell" containing a white powdery substance.
One (1) glass smoking device containing trace amounts of a white powdery substance.
One (1) clear plastic bag containing a white powdery substance and clear rock-like matter, suspected cocaine and methamphetamine.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
On 1/3/2023 at 1031 hours, I, TFC Rafer #6709, of the Maryland State Police, was assisting TFC Yocum #6934, with a DUI investigation.

During the course of the investigation, TFC Yocum determined probable cause to place Johnson under arrest. Johnsons arms did not have enough flexibility to be properly secured by one set of handcuffs. One cuff was latched onto Johnsons right wrist, and as TFC Yocum returned to retrieve a second set of MSP issued handcuffs from his vehicle, I stood with Johnson. Once Yocum cleared the front of his vehicle, Johnson threw both arms into the air in an attempt to break my grip, while simultaneously running to his right. I attempted to control both of Johnsons arms by reaching under his left and right armpit. Johnson took five steps to his right, then ran into a metal barrier fence. Johnson fell forward, hitting the ground with his face and chest.  As a result of continually trying to control both arms, I fell onto Johnsons back. I applied muscling techniques to Johnsons right arm as he was actively resisting and pulling his arm away from me.  TFC Yocum then assisted with additional muscling techniques in order to gain compliance.  I applied muscling techniques to Johnsons left arm, bringing both arms together to the small of his back. I secured a second handcuff to Johnsons left wrist, which was linked to the first set on Johnsons right wrist. At that time compliance was met and all force ceased.

Before placing Johnson in TFC Yocum's patrol vehicle, I assisted him with the search incident arrest. In Johnson's left pocket, I discovered a small clear corner baggie containing a white a white powdery substance and white rock-like substance. Due to my training, knowledge, and experience as a Maryland State Trooper, I suspected the white power to be Cocaine, a level II Controlled Dangerous Substance. I identified the rock substance as suspected methamphetamine, a Schedule II controlled dangerous substance. With the corner baggie I also discovered a clear plastic baggie containing a blue wax scraper with white powdery substance. I suspected this white powder substance to be fentanyl, a schedule II controlled dangerous substance. TFC Yocum took custody of the CDS.     

This concludes my involvement in this case.
